item.title: How to Earn Sand Coins in SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game
item.description:
SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game allows players to see Bikini Bottom through the eyes of their favorite pink starfish! Patrick Star takes the spotlight here, and as you run wild in the faithfully recreated undersea city, you'll come across plenty of familiar faces if you've seen the TV show.

Like in the TV show, Sand Dollar is the main currency in SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game . We've compiled this guide to help players figure out how to earn Sand Dollars in the game.

How to Get Sand Dollars in SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game

Sand Dollars are the main currency in Bikini Bottom, and players can earn them by taking part in various activities scattered throughout the undersea city. Activities in the game are divided into two categories: Quests and Feats.

Both of them reward you with Sand Dollars upon completion.

Earning Sand Dollars from Feats

Feats are the basic activities that you can find while exploring the world. For each region you explore in Bikini Bottom, you'll get a set of Feats that you can complete. The amount of Sand Dollars gained from completing each task can vary.

You'll have to discover new regions in Bikini Bottom to unlock new Feats. For example, once you find the Demolition Derby Stadium, you'll get the following Feats to complete:

  • Sunday, Sunday, Sunday: Bring a boatmobile to the Rage Room (5 Sand Dollars)
  • Hammer Throw: Throw a hammer to break a target in the Rage Room (10 Sand Dollars)
  • Mayo Hunt: Find all the Demolition Derby Stadium Mayo Jars (20 Sand Dollars)

You can find the list of Feats available by going to the Feats tab from your in-game menu.

Earning Sand Dollars from Quests

Quests are mini-games in SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game , which you can start by interacting with different characters in Bikini Bottom. Most quest mini-games have a time limit and three medals that players can unlock.

  • Bronze Medal: 15 Sand Dollars
  • Silver Medal: 20 Sand Dollars
  • Gold Medal: 25 Sand Dollars

Another type of quest offers a flat amount of Sand Dollars for completing a specific task. Squidward's Sunbathing is a good example of this type of quest, where you need to push NPCs out of a certain radius in order to complete it. Like Feats, you can check the Quest tab from your in-game menu to see a list of available quests.

Earning Sand Dollars is one of the main gameplay loops in SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game . As you earn more Sand Dollars, you'll be able to unlock new Costumes for Patrick and even get access to new activities in Bikini Bottom.

item.title: Black Myth: Wukong - 7 Bosses You Should Fight With The Pillar Stance
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Pillar Stance is crucial for countering agile bosses and long-range attacks with its defensive and range capabilities.
  • Timing and adaptability are key in utilizing Pillar Stance effectively against various boss attacks.
  • Combining Pillar Stance with specific abilities or spells can maximize damage output and defeat bosses more efficiently.

Black Myth: Wukong 's many boss fights all have their own nuances to them. Fortunately, players have a huge array of skills and abilities at their disposal, including three distinct fighting styles: Smash Stance, Pillar Stance and Thrust Stance. Each offers players a different way to use their attacks, though each style also comes with its own drawbacks and limitations.

Pillar Stance is widely considered to be the best stance in the game, particularly in the later chapters where opponents are more agile. Pillar Stance is primarily useful for its long range, allowing players to land strikes from further away than both Smash and Thrust stance. It can also be used in a defensive capacity to avoid ground-based attacks, typically elemental attacks or other special magic powers of certain enemies. This won't work on every boss, however, so a degree of adaptability will be necessary with each fight.

7 Whiteclad Noble

A Long-Range Counter Will Be Crucial Against This Agile Boss

Players will face off with the Whiteclad Nobl towards the end of Chapter One, leading to one of the best boss fights in the game. However, by this point, players should have enough Sparks to unlock a second stance, and Pillar Stance is the way to go when facing the Whiteclad Noble.

Due to his fast speed and ability to cover distance, the Whiteclad Noble can attack from range, equally retreating at speed when he comes under heavy attack. Pillar Stance will help to avoid some of his water-based attacks, too, but don't rely on the stance for defense.

6 Lang-Li-Guhh-Baw

Most Main Attacks Can Be Countered With Pillar Stance

Lang-Li-Gunh-Baw is an optional boss in Chapter Two, which players can take on as part of the Xu-Dog questline. This giant frog boss uses electrical attacks, often sending out shockwaves across the ground which cause immense amounts of damage.

Pillar Stance can be a great way to counter these attacks, and when timed correctly will greatly weaken Lang-Li-Gunh-Baw. Keep an eye on stamina, as holding the position at the top of the Pillar Stance for too long will cause the Destined One to fall.

5 Gore-Eye Daoist

Prevents Damage From Blood-Pool Ground Ability

The Gore-Eye Daoist is an optional miniboss players can find in Chapter Two after passing through the gates in the Drunken Boar side quest. Although not a major boss, it is worth seeking out the Gore-Eye Daoist to defeat him as doing so will grant a very powerful Spirit.

The Pillar Stance is by far the most effective of the three stances to use against this boss, since most of his attacks consist of creating dark energy pools of blood on the floor, which sap the player's health. Pillar Stance can avoid these attacks, while dealing a powerful counter attack in exchange.

4 Black Loong

Can Be Countered And Hit From Range

Black Loong is one of the more challenging bosses in Chapter Two, and can be very frustrating to deal with for players who don't have the right strategy. Though his attacks are quite slow, Black Loong makes use of Shock damage to create devastating attacks which can be hard to avoid.

As a result, players will need to spend much of the fight at a distance as they evade his ground-level shockwaves. While the Pillar Stance will not prevent Shock damage, it will enable players to spring counter attacks from a further distance than the other two stances, which is crucial for defeating Black Loong.

3 Yellow-Wind Sage

Long-Ranged Attacks Are Crucial To Counter The Sage's Agility

The Yellow-Wind Sage is one of the most difficult and frustrating bosses for most players at the end of Chapter Two. This difficult boss uses a range of different attacks and spells which neutrilize many of the player's best abilities.

Due to the high amount of dodges and evasion required, the Pillar Stance will be most effective for closing the distance, and can also help players to avoid some of the Yellow-Wind Sage's close-range attacks. The key to this fight is mobility, but the shorter range of the Smash Stance makes it less ideal for this particular fight.

2 Monk from the Sea

Can Be Easily Defeated With Pillar And Pluck Attack Combination

Monk from the Sea is a Yaoguai Chief players can encounter near Temple Entrance in Chapter Three. While not the most difficult boss fight in the game by any means, it can be an awkward one for players who are not prepared.

The best way to utilize Pillar Stance to defeat Monk from the Sea is in combination with attacking Duplicates from the Pluck of Many spell. When upgraded, the Duplicates will also deliver heavy attacks at the same time when a heavy combo is landed. Using Pillar Stance will ensure that the attacks deal the maximum possible damage together.

1 Venom Daoist

A Tricky Opponent With Ranged Attacks

The Venom Daoist is a difficult boss which players will have to defeat twice during Chapter Four. Both times, players will need to avoid a range of Poison attacks, which require lots of movement and agility, as well as Anti-Miasma Powder.

The Venom Doaist like to make leaping attacks from range, with a short window of opportunity to counter attack afterwards. Like most bosses who follow this pattern of attack, Pillar Stance offers the most fluid counter-attacking options to the player.

item.title: 7 Consoles With the Most Dragon Ball Games
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • The PlayStation 2 has the most DBZ games with 10, including all 3 Budokai & Tenkaichi titles.
  • The Nintendo DS managed to have 6 DBZ games, with Dragon Ball: Origins being the highest-rated.
  • The Xbox 360 won over the PS3 with 8 DBZ games, including a Kinect title & the same library as the PS3.

There are a ton of Dragon Ball games out there, be they fighting games, arena fighters, RPGs, collectible card games, etc. The opportunity to play a part in the Dragon Ball story, or blitz their friends with Big Bang Attacks, is one keen fans of the series can’t pass up. However, these chances often depended on which console they had.

Sega Saturn owners only had 2 DBZ games to import, which was an improvement over Genesis’ solitary entry. The original Xbox also only had the risible DBZ Sagas in its library. But if players had any of these machines, they had a wealth of DBZ games to play. This list only counts full-on DBZ games. Otherwise, it would have to calculate the fractions over how much DBZ to One Piece/Naruto/Gintama/Reborn , etc., crossover games like Jump Super Stars have.

7 Nintendo DS

When 6 Games Are More Than Enough

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball: Origins
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Harukanaru Densetsu

Just making the list, the Nintendo DS managed to have just one more game over the last generation of consoles, as the PS4, Xbox One, and Switch all have 5 games apiece. However, that could all change, as the Switch and PS4 are still active. They won’t be getting Dragon Ball Sparking Zero anytime soon, though they could get a compilation or re-release of older games.

For example, the DS went through the original Dragon Ball series in the DB: Origins duology, and the Saiyan arc in DBZ: Attack of the Saiyans . DBZ: Supersonic Warriors 2 was an improvement over its GBA predecessor, as was DB Kai: Ultimate Butouden over DB GT: Final Bout on the PS1. While DBZ: Harukanaru Densetsu lets players battle it out with cards instead of ki.

6 SNES/Super Famicom

7 Games, 16 Bits, Plenty of Fun

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Hyper Dimension
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Super Saiya Densetsu

By the time DBZ reached the West, the SNES , or Super Famicom , was fading out and the PS1 was on the rise. This might be why only a handful of its 7 DBZ games made it out of Japan. Even then, they usually turned up in mainland Europe over North America, like the Butouden games. As simplistic as they are now, they were to the 16-bit era what the Budokai games are to the 128-bit era.

Still, if people didn’t like Butouden ’s scrappy-looking sprites, TOSE cleaned them up for DBZ: Hyper Dimension . Then, for RPG fans, the two Super Gokuden games went through Goku’s story from the start of DB to when he went Super Saiyan against Freeza on Planet Namek. While DBZ: Super Saiya Densetsu was essentially a remake of 2 Famicom card-based RPGs put together.

5 PlayStation 3

Managing Lucky 7 Entries

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Burst Limit
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Z

Technically, one could say the PlayStation 3 had 8 DBZ games, as the Budokai HD Collection had 2 games on it. But they’re only available on one disc as they didn’t get separate digital releases before they were delisted from the PS3 store. As such, it just became one of 7 games to make up the console’s DBZ library.

Fans had a reasonable bunch of games to play, though they were a step down from the previous generation. The two Raging Blast games were average at best, as was Ultimate Tenkaichi. Burst Limit was okay though not as solid as the Budokai games, and Battle of Z only thrived while players were online. It did get the first Xenoverse game, even if it was a down-port of the PS4 version.

4 Xbox 360

Edging Out the Competition with 8 Games

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Burst Limit
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z for Kinect

With the PS3’s terrible launch and tricky cell processor, it’s perhaps no surprise that the Xbox 360 ended up getting ahead. Console-exclusive series like Tekken went multi-format to give the new console some games, and the likes of Dimps, Spike, Artdink, etc., took the chance to port their wares to the machine. Which is why the 360 has the exact same library of games as the PS3.

Burst Limit , Ultimate Tenkaichi , Battle of Z , Xenoverse 1 , the Budokai collection, and both Raging Blast games could be run on Microsoft’s box of wonders just as well as Sony’s pricey machine. Then it got one more, as DBZ for Kinect tried to use the 360’s maligned motion-detecting webcam for its controls. It didn’t work, but it was still enough to give the machine more DBZ games than the PS3.

3 NES/Famicom

Two Irresistible Forces Clash to Produce 8 Games

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z 2: Gekishin Freeza
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball: Shenron no Nazo (Dragon Power)

The Famicom (aka the NES ) was already a Japanese phenomenon when Goku first met Bulma in the woods in Dragon Ball . But the strip was such a smash that it got a wealth of games on the console. Fans might recognize the first, DB: Shenron no Nazo , as it got a Western release. Except, since no one knew what a ‘Goku’ was back then, it was turned into Dragon Power . It's a strange game to go back to now that DBZ has caught on worldwide.

The rest stayed in Japan, with many of the games being RPGs. DBZ: Gekitou Tenkaichi Budokai stood out as it came with a card reader accessory that let players add characters and items by swiping cards against it. The rest, from Daimaou Fukkatsu to Ressen Jinzouningen , used in-game cards, until DBZ Gaiden stuck to regular RPG action for an original story where Goku & co had to stop the evil Dr Lychee from eradicating the Saiyans.

2 Game Boy Advance

8 Ways to Game with Goku on the Go

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: The Legacy of Goku 2
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Taiketsu

By the early 2000s, DBZ was global in its appeal, with an international audience eager to play more than the scant offerings on the PS1. The GameCube was out of luck, offering just 3 DBZ games (though its versions of Budokai 1 & 2 are arguably the best). However, Nintendo fans still had hope to get some DBZ action if they had a handheld like the Game Boy Advance .

The device is still the handheld with the most DBZ games on it, even over mobile phones. They weren’t all winners, like the dreadful DBZ: Taiketsu and the iffy Legacy of Goku . But Legacy of Goku 2 was a vast improvement, Buu’s Fury was solid, and Supersonic Warriors offered a much better fighting game experience than Taiketsu .

1 PlayStation 2

Sets the Number for Other Consoles to Beat at 10

  • Highest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Budokai 3
  • Lowest Rated Game: Dragon Ball Z: Sagas

Handhelds are fine and all, but when it comes to consoles, the PlayStation 2 still has the most to offer DB fans. Owners of the mighty machine could treat themselves to all 3 Budokai games, all 3 Budokai Tenkaichi games (the precursors to Sparking Zero ), the underrated Super Dragon Ball Z , and the rightly slated DBZ: Sagas and DBZ: Infinite World.

However, if those fans tried to collect all 10 games, they’d have trouble finding that last one. DBZ 2 V was a souped-up version of Budokai 2 released only in Japan as part of a contest held by V-Jump magazine. Only 2,000 discs at best still exist, and it came with all its content unlocked at the start, and Cooler and Kuriza as alternate skins for Freeza.

item.title: Do You Need to Play Silent Hill 1 Before Silent Hill 2?
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Is Silent Hill 2's Story a Continuation of Silent Hill 1?
  • Should You Play Silent Hill 1 Before Silent Hill 2?

Silent Hill 1 is considered a hallmark of the psychological horror genre due to its spin-chilling atmosphere, memorable characters, and terrifying monsters. With the release of Silent Hill 2 Remake , players are wondering if it's crucial to play the original Silent Hill before playing Silent Hill 2 . This article will go over both of these installments in this psychological survival horror and determine if players need to experience the original before diving into the sequel's remake.

Spoilers for Silent Hill 1 below, proceed with caution.

Is Silent Hill 2's Story a Continuation of Silent Hill 1?

The story opens up with a father, Harry Mason, and his daughter, Cheryl Mason, traveling to the town of Silent Hill. After driving up the twists and turns of the road leading up to the town, Harry quickly swerves the car to avoid hitting a little schoolgirl in the middle of the road, which causes an accident and his passing out. After gaining consciousness, Harry realizes his daughter is missing from the car and heads into the town to find his missing daughter.

This starts a chain of events with Harry facing off against different monstrosities, experiencing the horrors of the town, and uncovering the dark secret behind the town's cult. As the story reaches its climax and the story starts to unravel, players find out that Cheryl was part of Alessa, a girl who was to become a vessel for the cult's demon god.

Now that Cheryl and Alessa are united, the Incubus is born, and it's up to Harry to take it down. After players successfully defeat this final boss, Alyssa hands over her newborn reincarnation to Harry. Later, Harry makes his escape from the collapsing bowels of Silent Hill and decides to raise the child as his own under the name of Heather Mason.

So the question is, does this story continue in the Silent Hill 2 remake ? The answer is no . Silent Hill 2's story is completely different and isolated from the plot in the original. The sequel gets a new protagonist by the name of James Sunderland, who receives a letter from his deceased wife telling him to come find her in Silent Hill. Without giving out any spoilers, the entire focus of Silent Hill 2 is centered around James coming face to face with his inner demons while braving the hellish town in search of his wife. This plot is isolated from the story of Silent Hill 1 .

Should You Play Silent Hill 1 Before Silent Hill 2?

Players don't necessarily have to play Silent Hill 1 in order to understand the story of Silent Hill 2 . However, Silent Hill 1 is the most important game in the series as it goes into a bit more detail about the town's history. Alessa is one of the most pivotal characters in the franchise as her story shapes the landscape of this town into a hellish realm.

So, if you want a deeper understanding of Silent Hill lore, it's highly recommended to play Silent Hill 1 . Otherwise, players can opt to directly venture into Silent Hill 2 and expect to have a great time without missing out on any story elements.

However, if you've enjoyed Silent Hill 1 and are looking to play a true follow-up to the game in terms of narrative, you should play Silent Hill 3 as that game is a direct continuation of the original.

item.title: Genshin Impact 5.1 Maintenance Start & End Time
item.description:
Quick Links

  • When Is Genshin Impact 5.1 Coming Out?
  • Genshin Impact 5.1 Maintenance Ends & Start Time
  • Genshin Impact 5.1 Release Date & Time

After the constant fighting with authorities in Inazuma, Sumeru, and Fontaine in Genshin Impact , players finally circle back to working with the nation to solve a certain crisis. When Natlan was first announced, HoYoverse teased several characters that are set to be 5-star units. This includes Mualani, Kinich, Xilonen, Chasca, Citlali, and Iansan. After Mualani and Kinich debuted in version 5.0, it's now Xilonen's turn in 5.1.

According to the drip marketing, it looks like Genshin 5.2 won't bring the Pyro Archon, Mavuika, but will instead feature Chasca. This means Travelers must wait longer to bring a new Archon into their team. But for now, players can enjoy the assistance of Xilonen, whom they can pull for on the day of Genshin Impact 5.1 release date , right after the maintenance ends .

When Is Genshin Impact 5.1 Coming Out?

Genshin Impact 5.1 is coming out on October 8, 2024 (UTC-4 or earlier) , or October 9, 2024 (UTC-3 or later) , depending on the players' timezone. The update introduces a new 5-star character, Xilonen, and will feature Chiori, Hu Tao, and Nahida reruns.

Genshin Impact 5.1 Maintenance Ends & Start Time

Genshin Impact 5.1 maintenance is set to start on October 8, 2024, from 06:00 PM until 11:00 PM (UTC-4) , so the maintenance is scheduled to last for five hours. Here's a list of Genshin 5.1 maintenance start and end times:
